reviewText: I bought this game thinking I was going to have a nice relaxing time flying about in space just like Sandra Bullock in Gravity before ♥♥♥♥ hit the fan, and I was not disappointed. For the low price that it is, Astronaut Simulator is reasonably well received in my eyes. Simulator? Not entirely immersive, but the control scheme does require some practice before you get the hang of it. But what do you expect for a less-than £5 title?\n\nThere are obviously much more immersive and/or higher-detailed games out there for us space-sim lovers, but honestly I had fun playing around with this for the shorter-half of an hour on my alternate account. And I'm sure I will continue to enjoy it when I feel like I need a break from the more hardcore simulations I frequent.

reviewText: WOW... for a 6 dollar game this is not bad at al. Its verry simplistic, all you have to do is move around The Endeavor and other space Shuttles and fix things, yet it can get SUPER intense when you loose control of yourself and slowly start drifting off in to the Deep Dark space that awaits to devour you, ya it can get kinda scary too. Its a great little game, and if you like anything to do with space this is somthing you will want to have in your library. If that sounds interesting then this is something you will defenitly wanna pick up.\n

reviewText:
Astronaut Simulator is definitely not for everyone.

=======

CONS:

- Hard to control: takes a LOT of practice; easy to press the wrong key and botch everything.
- Frustration level = MAXIMUM OVERLOAD
- Looping audio for missions: gets a tad annoying when you have to repeat the mission so many times.


PROS:
+ Good atmosphere: visuals are good, and the aesthetic is on-point
+ True to life: Using the N2 to control your movement in space is right-on.
+ Very precise


Do I recommend?
Well... yes. It's a very good game to give a go at, but I wouldn't say it's for everyone.

It can be extremely frustrating trying to get through the very first level (if you can), as you have to really try to control the precise movements of the astronaut. Small movements are important (very few button presses to release N2), and taking your time is crucial. It's very easy to screw up, so make sure you're pressing the right button, or you may go into a panicked frenzy of button pressing that jetisons you off into the darkest regions of the nether that is space..!

...

Don't buy it if you can't handle a good challenge, or don't have a lot of time to spare in getting really good at pretending to be an astronaut.

reviewText: For those old enough, the controls remind me very much of Descent from the 1990's: The first few flights you'll find yourself disorientated and occasionally spinning helplessly in space, but after a while you'll surprise yourself by pulling some very smooth moves, like orbiting around objects and changing your orientation while flying backwards. Simple in the surface but very rewarding. And for those wondering, it works fine with the keyboard,

reviewText:
UPDATE!! 6/12/15 I REFUNDED THIS GAME!


Please respect my opion.

So I checked this game out thinking wow, as a simulator nut freak this looks pretty cool.
How I was wrong.
I jumped into game with a 360 controller at first thinking wow has control support nice" The controls on the controler were garbage and uncontrolable. I could barely move with it and only got to one checkpoint in the tut before losing energy and not be able to stop spinning. So I pretty much laughed the game off for awhile untill today
date: I came to the conclusion to try it again. We'll Let me point this out
recommended:
The controls are a little better and controlable with a keyboard they're still a bit wacky. I almost finished the tut before running out of energy. I made up my mind to try a mission. I was doing great untill I realized the energy bar is sooooo stupid. It's like trying  to keep a charge on a Ipod 1st Gen. The game is relaxing but needs quite a bit of help. If this game had like mechanics where your hands and stuff move or when you fix something you actuallly have a animation. Or even a bit more distinct way of finding the objectives.
*Pros.
*Pretty Decent Graphcs and Designs.
*Good Specs.
*Really cool voice clips from real space missions.
*Decent music.
*Gamepad support (HIGHLY UNRECOMMENDED)

*Cons.
*Terrible movement.
*Energy bar runs out WAY to fast.
* I'd like to do missions inside the cabin too.
*Once out of control with no energy you're done
*The two little boxes that display info are kinda tacky.
*No user menu interface. (Can't change video

reviewText:
An OK game with much potential, but the somewhat poor textures on the Space Shuttle, simple and repetative missions, and lack of options (to turn the sound down, increase graphics etc) just narrowly bring the game down.

There isn't much good to say about this game. If it had more content, or you could interact more with theshuttle when working on it, I think this would be a good game.

I would rate this 4/10 but because with one or 2 simple updates it could be massively improved, I will recommend this game. I doubt those updates will ever come and more content will never be seen, but heigh-ho.

reviewText:
I think my most favourite part about the game is how realistic it is when it comes to the atmosphere / physics of it, it's very easily to lose control and drift off if you're not careful.

The controls are kind-of difficult to understand at first but it gets easier the more you play it, as you get used to the controls and how to move in a zero-gravity environment.

I personally think improvement could be put in surroundings, maybe with more detail into the stars instead of flying bits of triangles everywhere, or maybe a space shuttle or something, but this doesn't really effect the game play at all.

Overall it's a great game, 8/10.
